official-title.#text: To authorize and request the President to award the Medal of Honor posthumously to First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing for acts of valor during the Civil War.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: Alonzo H. Cushing was born in Delafield, Wisconsin, on January 19, 1841.
Alonzo H. Cushing graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point, New York, on June 24, 1861.

quote.#tail: on Cemetery Ridge during the Battle of Gettysburg.

text.#text: On July 3, 1863, First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing commanded Battery A, 4th United States Artillery, Army of the Potomac, in the defense of the
During the battle, First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing was shot multiple times, but refused to retreat.
First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing continued to command his battery until he was shot and killed.
The Union victory at the Battle of Gettysburg was one of the key turning points in the Civil War.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: have determined that the actions of First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing do merit the award of the Medal of Honor.

header.#text: Authorization for award of the Medal of Honor to First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing for acts of valor during the Civil War

to then First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing for conspicuous acts of gallantry and intrepidity at the risk of life and beyond the call of duty in the Civil War, as described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: are the actions of then First Lieutenant Alonzo H. Cushing while in command of Battery A, 4th United States Artillery, Army of the Potomac, at Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, on July 3, 1863, during the American Civil War.
